reviewText:
Online co-op or split screen local co-op game with up to around 30 possible characters to play as square block figures. Has a total of around 25 co-op maps, a set of 5 different survival co-op challenges and 1 singleplayer survival challenge map. Depending on connection with co-op partner, each level has sufficient variety and tests the movement, puzzle-solving skill and teamwork in you and your co-op partner. Achievements are relatively easy to get with a decent co-op partner. The singleplayer map is also relatively easy to finish and unlock achievement and playable characters.

Among the cons, there is one very difficult level that is much harder than the rest, and online connection can be troublesome sometimes as the Steam game invite function does not always register in the other person's game.

Overall, I would recommend this game only if you have a friend or family member who can play the game online or local co-op with you and only when the game is at discount as it takes less than 10 hours to finish all maps and unlock all possible playable characters and character accessories.

reviewText:
IMPORTANT NOTE: This is a coop-only game. You WILL need a coop buddy to play with. Voice-chat is highly recommended. It is best played via Local-Coop, but Online-Coop is playable too if you can get the network working.

Gameplay
this is a top-down puzzle game that emphasizes on solving puzzles in coop. It has about 30 different levels, starting from easy levels that introduce game mechanics, to the harder ones that you really need to have some time trying and thinking. You can complete the game in 2-3 hours.

The puzzles themselves are not hard, and most of them rely on solving in coop. For example, in one of the early stages, player one can see landmines, player two can shoot enemies. Both players have to traverse together to avoid stepping on landmines while shooting the enemies to keep both players safe.

The graphics and musics are simple and cute, it suits the game pretty well. As a simple indie game, you don't need to have a high-spec rig to play this game. But you might want to tone down the in-game volume so you can use voice-chat.

The hardest stage is very frustrating though. It is hard in a very frustrating way, and to win that stage you will need to be extremely lucky.

Online-Coop Network Issues
I play Online-Coop with my friend, and we encountered quite a lot of connection issues. For one, it has some random lags while playing (even though we are very sure our network is working very fine). Glitches occurs occasionally after the lag is recovered. Since this game is not that popular, there are very few network-issue solutions online.

We have to keep doing trial-and-error to find an optimal network solution when playing this, sometimes we need to switch host, sometimes it is better when we both use VPN etc. It is very inconsistent.

And because of the network issues, we struggled in a lot of harder stages, since some of them rely on coop timing. That is why, playing in Local-Coop is highly recommended.

One tip for improving the network lag while playing Online-Coop: make sure both players are using the same graphics settings (especially the screen resolution). It helps in my case.

For Achievement Hunters
Most of the achievements are easily doable. However the hardest stage is extremely luck-based and very very frustrating to clear, making one of the achievement hard to get.

Some of the achievements cannot be unlocked by the host player, therefore you will need to play in Online-Coop and take turns hosting for both players to unlock those. Not sure if this is a glitch or dev-intended.

My score: 6/10

reviewText:
Space Farmers is a very interesting game, but serious issues plague what could be a great fantastic co op game.

The game is basically a two player co op game where you play as two farmers who try to escape a space ship, by completing tons of goals.

The game consists of 30 levels which you can pick any of them to complete. After the first 10 random levels you can pick any route you want, since you can only do 5 levels per route.

The gameplay consists of you trying to solve with your friend and trust me you will need someone with a mic that you can talk to, cause you will need someone to figure out the puzzles with.

The puzzles range from trying to get to the end of the level by activating switches, killing robots with different weapons and gadgets. They very from shotguns to pistols, to explosives, you also have gadgets like jetpacks, x ray glasses and torches.

The game is incredibly fun with a friend, but there is also a lot of bad.

The controls are for the most part really fluid, but there are some bits that are incredibly annoying to control ( you will know once you see it).

First of all the soundtrack is atrocious. It really hurts the ears while you're playing, overall the audio design is really mediocre, not to mention when talking on skype or through any other software it's gonna be incredibly hard to hear what your friend has to say, cause even then the sound is way too loud.

The game also has some level design issues. Like some really hard stuff. Now hard stuff isn't bad, but some of the stuff in the game is incredibly unfair.

The game took me 4 hours to finish. There is some replay value to do the extra achievements and there's also a challenge room to test your skills.

Overall do I recommend Space Farmers ? For the full price no, but once it goes on sale definitely give it a try and give the second copy to your friend and have yourself a good ol time.

Pros:
+Great puzzles
+Fun Gameplay
+Good Co Op

Cons:
-Terrible music
-Clunky controls


Final Rating:
7/10

reviewText:
Before getting into this review, I would just like to point out that there is more to farming than pigs and bad banjo tunes.

Now that the disgruntled country kid inside me is satisfied, what exactly is Space Farmers? Essentially, it's a coop only puzzle (maybe?) game, designed to be played in short 5 level runs through self contained rooms that each focus on a particular theme or item. At times that's as easy as running from point A-B, other times you'll need to direct a robotic bull by using a rather distracting hat, or move pigs onto buttons to keep doors from closing.

I rather like the idea of semi random, varied objectives and play styles something along the lines of WarioWare, with a short playtime requirement and some goofy customization options, but Space Farmers just comes across as so incredibly lazy in its design. It's constantly punishing for the slightest mistakes, never explains anything about itself (instead asking you to navigate outside of the game to a webpage to read a how-to), and forces you to replay the same tired levels over and over again do to there being no way to select which you want to play or even simply limit them to ones you haven't already gone through. The presentation is unremarkable and unpolished, with an unhelpful UI, and mediocre controller support, not to mention a general instability that saw the game crashing numerous times in just the hour or so I spent playing.

It's a tediously dull game all around, in ways that seem like so easily avoidable and amendable, but despite its frequent content updates its issues are so ingrained at this point that I'm not sure they could be fixed in a simple patch, leaving me pessimistic it will ever turn into something worthwhile.

reviewText:
Played this game at a games con a little while ago, and thoroughly enjoyed the alpha build I played on, so when I found it was on steam, now a few months on, I knew I had to get hold of it, as of now, I've played about an hour of the game through with a friend and we both enjoyed the way the game played.

Things I loved:
[Level Design]  The game instantly throws you in at the deep end, with a rather complex first level, which is quite hard to one shot, but instead teaches you to learn the levels features, so on and so forth.  The first level took us around 15 tries, but by the end we knew how the level worked and had no trouble getting through it.
[Turnips]  I adore this in-game currency, firstly because it is not gained through micro transactions, you have to work to get them. Secondly, the way you use it, picture the scene, you are low on health, and have just reached a tough part in the level where you KNOW you are going to get hit, ta-da!  There is a health-dispenser that costs 10 turnips per 10% of your health restored, genius.  And not only can it be used for this, but the game has a decent variety of customization for the user, after a run of the game, you can go back and edit your player, some items are already unlocked for you, but with turnips, you can unlock some lovely clothing and character player models.  My favourite custom item being the fez.
[Co-op]  This is the most co-op based co-op game on the market as of right now,  well, that and portal 2, but for now we'll focus on the game shall we?  There are genius puzzles of the game for players to bang their heads on the desk at, not because it isn't fun, because it's difficult to get used too. No 2 puzzles in the game are similar, each level introduces a new way of solving it, one of my favourites is the invisible path level. You literally have to direct your partner through what to them looks like nothing but air.

Ok, we've done good things, but there were a few bit's and pieces of the game I wasn't so sure about:

[Menu]  This game has some absolutely fantastic elements in it, and I love it to bits, BUT the menu, the thing you see when you load the game up, could look... better...  compared to the rest of the game, it kind of let it down.
[Choosing levels]  When we had finished the first 5 or so levels, the game took us to a little hall, with a funny looking band playing music, and I was dumb enough to tell my friend to step on the pressure plate nearest to the entrance.  It started the game again...  And also seemed to shuffle in levels we hadn't played yet, at this point we decided to stop playing for the day, very confused.


That's all I really have to say about this fantastic Indie game.  Thanks for adding some awesome new things, and apologies for not finding everything so up to scratch.

I honestly have no idea what all of these drones are talking about in these positive reviews.

There are 30* (incorrectly said 20 before), 5-6 minute long levels. Once you've beaten it once, there's really no difficulty in beating it again, most just have one mediocre puzzle, some having no puzzle at all and just requiring you to run.

At the price point of you and your friend needing to spend $10 (previously said $20, but you get a double pack) to play this game (There is no single player), it is absolutely not worth it by ANY stretch of the imagination.

The issue with the level design is there is no varience, it is using the two items given to you at the start to solve the singular gimic. It's like getting a power up in other games, such as in Metroid Prime when you get the power shot upgrade, you already immediately know that the next solution is to use the power shot to solve it. Fortunately, in a game like that, the length allows more opportunites to use what you have in combination or solve puzzles or beat bosses, but in a game with this design, where the levels are 5 to 6 minutes long, there is no puzzle on a lot of levels, it's use the new introduced item to clear the level. The level with the potato bomb or whatever launcher and the gloves that let you pick up bigger things are clear examples, I didn't bother playing the other 10 or so that are randomly given to you until you beat so many levels or whatever the stipulation is to choose your own levels, freeing you from the chains of random selection that can force you to play through the same simplistic levels. I wouldn't recommend this game if it had 100 levels in the same style.

I'd highly suggest anyone looking to pick up a co-op game to explore other titles such as Hammerwatch or Risk of Rain at similar price points.

It's a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• poor game that promises more, but has no reason to give anymore. I don't recommend this at all.
